sect2.para: Toybox combines common Linux command line utilities together into a single executable. Its major design goals are simplicity, smallness and speed. It is an alternative to BusyBox which focuses on standards more than on compatibility with its GNU counterparts.

sect2.title: Installation of toybox
sect2.para: First apply the following patch to allow building with the ash shell:
Ensure the toybox source is completely clean:

screen.userinput: install -v -m 755 toybox /bin ln -sfv toybox /bin/cat ln -sfv toybox /bin/chgrp ln -sfv toybox /bin/chmod ln -sfv toybox /bin/chown ln -sfv toybox /bin/cp ln -sfv toybox /bin/cpio ln seglistitem.seg: acpi, basename, blkid, blockdev, toybox, bzcat, cal, cat, chgrp, chmod, chown, chroot, cksum, cmp, comm, cp, cpio, cut, date, df, dirname, dmesg, dos2unix, du, echo, egrep, eject, env, expand, factor, fallocate, false, fgrep, find, free, fsfreeze, grep, groups, halt, head, hostname, id, ifconfig, insmod, install, kill, killall, killall5, link, ln, login, logname, losetup, ls, lsmod, lspci, lsusb, md5sum, mkdir, mkfifo, mknod, mkswap, mktemp, modinfo, mount, mountpoint, mv, nice, nl, nohup, od, partprobe, paste, patch, pidof, pivot_root, pmap, poweroff, printenv, pwd, pwdx, readlink, realpath, reboot, renice, rev, rfkill, rm, rmdir, rmmod, seq, setsid, sha1sum, sleep, sort, split, stat, su, swapoff, swapon, switch_root, sync, sysctl, tac, tail, taskset, tee, time, timeout, touch, true, truncate, tty, umount, uname, uniq, unix2dos, unlink, unshare, uptime, uudecode, uuencode, vmstat, wc, which, who, whoami, xargs, and yes

listitem.para: Shows status of power sources and thermal devices.
Strips any path and a given suffix from a file name.
Prints UUIDs of all file systems.
Calls block device ioctls from the command line.
Combines many common Unix utilities into a single executable.
Decompresses bzipped files to standard output.
Displays a simple calendar.
Concatenates files to standard output.
Changes the group ownership of files and directories.
Changes the permissions of each file to the given mode.
Changes the user and/or group ownership of files and directories.
Runs a command with the specified directory as the root directory.
Calculates the CRC32 checksums of files.
Compares two files and reports whether or in which bytes they differ.
Compares two sorted files.
Copies files.
Copies files into and out of a cpio archive.
Prints selected fields from each input file.
Displays the current time in the given format, or sets the system time.
Prints file system usage statistics.
Strips the non-directory suffix from a file name.
Prints or controls the kernel ring buffer.
Converts files from DOS to Unix format.
Summarizes disk space used for each file and/or directory.
Displays the given strings.
Prints lines matching an extended regular expression.
Ejects removable media.
Runs a command in a specified environment.
Converts tabs to spaces.
Factors integers.
Tells the filesystem to allocate space for a file.
Returns an exit status code indicating failure.
Prints lines matching a list of fixed strings.
Searches for files and performs actions on them.
Displays the amount of free and used system memory.
Freezes or unfreezes a filesystem.
Prints lines matching a basic regular expression.
Reports the group memberships of user.
Halts the system.
Prints the first ten lines of each given file.
Shows or sets system host name.
Reports information about the current user or specified user.
Configures a network interface.
Loads the specified kernel module into the running kernel.
Copies files and sets attributes.
Sends signals to processes.
Sends a signal to given processes.
Send a signal to all processes outside current session.
Creates hardlink to a file.
Makes links between files.
Begins a new session on the system.
Reports the current user's login name.
Sets up and controls loop devices.
Lists directory contents.
Lists currently loaded kernel modules.
Lists all PCI devices.
Lists all USB buses and devices.
Prints or checks MD5 checksums.
Creates directories with the given names.
Creates a named pipe.
Creates device nodes with the given names.
Initializes the given block device to be used as a swap area.
Creates a temporary file with name based on template.
Examines an object file associated with a kernel module and displays any information that it can glean.
Mounts a file system.
Checks if the directory is a mountpoint.
Moves or renames files or directories.
Runs a program with modified scheduling priority.
Numbers lines of input.
Runs a command immune to hangups.
Dumps files in octal and other formats.
Tells the kernel about partition table changes.
Replaces newlines in files.
Modifies files according to a patch file.
Looks up processes based on their name.
Makes the given file system the new root file system of the current process.
Displays detailed process memory usage.
Halts the system and shuts off power.
Prints the environment.
Reports the name of the current working directory.
Reports the current working directory of a process.
Reports the value of the given symbolic link.
Prints the resolved path of the given file.
Reboots the system.
Alters the priority of running processes.
Reverses the lines of a given file.
Enables or disables wireless devices.
Removes files or directories.
Removes directories if they are empty.
Unloads kernel modules from the running kernel.
Prints a sequence of numbers within a given range and with a given increment.
Runs the given program in a new session.
Prints or checks SHA1 checksums.
Pauses for the given amount of time.
Sorts lines of text.
Splits the given file by size or by number of lines.
Displays file or file system status.
Runs a shell with substitute user ID.
Disables devices for paging and swapping.
Enables devices for paging and swapping.
Switches to another filesystem as the root of the mount tree.
Writes all buffered blocks to disk.
Modifies kernel parameters at run time.
Concatenates the given files in reverse.
Prints the last ten lines of each given file.
Launches a new task which may only run on certain processors, or changes the processor affinity of an exisitng PID..
Reads from standard input while writing both to standard output and to the given files.
Runs program and displays resource usage when it exits.
Runs a command with a time limit.
Changes file timestamps.
Returns a status code indicating success.
Sets length of file(s), extending sparsely if necessary.
Reports the file name of the terminal connected to standard input.
Unmounts file systems.
Reports system information.
Discards duplicate lines.
Converts files from Unix to DOS format.
Deletes one file.
Creates new namespace(s) for a process and its children.
Displays the time since the last boot.
Decodes the uuencoded file.
Reads a file and writes an encoded version to the standard output.
Prints virtual memory statistics.
Count lines, words, and bytes for each given file.
Locates a command.
Shows who is logged on.
Reports the user name associated with the current effective user ID.
Runs a given command to a list of files.
Repeatedly outputs 'y' or a given string until killed.
